items.content_html:
Summary

Fine-grained PATs today are limited to only the user or organization namespace they are created for. This hinders inner-source use, where repositories in another organization in your enterprise are marked internal . With this change, fine-grained PATs will optionally be able to access internal repositories from the same enterprise, if the token is scoped to an enterprise-owned organization.

Intended Outcome

Inner-source is a critical feature for enterprise developers collaborating on GitHub, allowing them to share code and dependencies within their enterprise freely. Supporting that in fine-grained PATs makes it easier to use these tokens in inner-source scenarios.

How will it work?

A checkbox will appear in the fine-grained PAT creation settings when an enterprise-owned organization is chosen as the resource owner. This checkbox will be checked by default, and when checked, indicates that the token is allowed to access inner-sourced data in the enterprise that owns the chosen organization.
items.title: Fine-grained PAT support for inner-source repositories

items.content_html:
Summary

You'll gain an enhanced view of the security risk page allowing you to see a count per repository of security alerts by alert severity or security feature.

Intended Outcome

Today, enterprises users need to be able to view a total count of alerts by severity or by security feature for a group of repositories.

This feature aims to give users dynamic views to enable users to quickly and easily identify the most critical security risks and prioritize their remediation efforts.

How will it work?

Users will be presented with a toggle on the security risk page to switch between two different row-level presentations: a sum of alerts by alert severity across all security features, and a sum of alerts by security feature across all alert severities.
items.title: Enhancing the security risk page with grouped alert counts

items.content_html:
Summary

We are providing users with the ability to set column limits on the board layout, based off of the number of items in a specific board column. These can be set per column, and are unique to each board layout.

Intended Outcome

By setting and visually highlighting limits on the number of items in a column on a board, users and teams will be able to prioritize their work through the different stages of development. This will increase focus and clarity on the most important work items.

How will it work?

Users will be able to set a per-column limit for the number of work items in a board column that is unique to each board. The count of items and column limit will be surfaced at the top of a board column in a pill (ex: 4/8), and it will be visually highlighted when the limit is reached to indicate to a user that they have reached the limit. Users will not be restricted to moving new items to a column, so it acts as a "soft" limit.
items.title: Projects: Board column limits

items.content_html:
Summary

We are providing users with the ability to specify a field as a swimlane on their boards, allowing them to view their items in a horizontal grouping to visually separate and distinguish between work that belongs to different workstreams, team members, or priorities.

Intended Outcome

By providing users with the ability to specify a field as a swimlane on their boards, we can help them with tasks such as

  • Viewing high priority items alongside items with lower priority, to help draw attention to the most important work and what requires immediate attention
  • Viewing different work streams side-by-side to view the progress of the work for ongoing projects and across teams in a single view
  • Viewing items across team members to see how work breaks down within the team and how it is progressing together

This swimlane view gives users a single zoomed out or stacked view that allows them to stay in one place, without losing the context of how this work compares to each other and is progressing together.

How will it work?

Users will be able to specify a field as a swimlane that is unique to each board. The swimlanes act as a horizontal grouping on board layouts, and items will be able to be moved between swimlanes to make adjustments and update the field value.
items.title: Projects: Board swimlanes

items.content_html:
Summary

We are providing users with the ability to create a pivot view on all project layouts (table, board, and roadmap). Users will be able to select a pivot field that pulls all values into a sticky pivot panel on the left side, with the project items in the layout on the right side. Clicking through the pivot values in the panel will filter and adjust the items that appear in the view, allowing users to quickly page through their items and make adjustments.

Intended Outcome

By providing users with the ability to create a pivot view on their projects, we can help them accomplish tasks such as

  • Visually separating and breaking down epics from the individual tasks with a Tracked by pivot, giving a hierarchical view of your items powered by tasklists to understand how larger work items are progressing in a single view
  • Planning out current and upcoming iterations with an iteration field pivot, allowing users to quickly make adjustments to when work will begin if plans change
  • Understanding team capacity with an Assignee pivot, breaking down work items by each distinct assignee and giving an easy canvas to move items between team members to reassign work

How will it work?

Users will be able to specify a field as the pivot for any of their table, board, or roadmap layouts. The pivot panel allows a user to select a value from the list that populates and filters the work items that appear in the view on the right.
items.title: Projects: Pivot panel

items.content_html:
Summary

At both the enterprise and organization levels, you will be able to easily filter the security overview data by repository properties, giving you the ability to more efficiently analyze and manage security risks.

Intended Outcome

Enterprises users have long-requested the ability to group their repositories for easier monitoring of code security status within security overview. Users have specifically requested the ability to filter the risk and coverage views and alert-centric view in security overview by a specific subset of repositories, rather than having to look at all repositories at once.

How will it work?

With this feature, repository properties will be automatically available for filtering via the search bar. This means that you can easily search for specific repositories and filter results based on various repository properties you have setup.
items.title: Repository properties integration with security overview

items.content_html:
Summary

At the organization level, you will be able to enhance the security of your repositories by easily choosing the security-extended query suite when enabling code scanning default setup for multiple repositories.

Intended Outcome

Enterprises users have requested the ability to enable CodeQL at scale and use the security-extended query suite. Currently, the only way to enable CodeQL with the security-extended query suite is at the repository level. This creates a significant workload for users and leads to dissatisfaction with the process.

This feature makes that job easier.

How will it work?

With this feature, you will be able choose between the security-extended and the default query suite when enabling repositories at the organization level when using the "enable all" feature or the multi-repo enablement feature on the security coverage page.
items.title: Code scanning default setup makes it possible to use security-extended CodeQL query suite across your organization

items.content_html:
Summary

At the enterprise level, you will be able to view a trend of security feature enablement and security alerts in order to analyze your security program's performance.

Intended Outcome

Today, enterprise users can see only the current status of security alerts and security feature enablement at the enterprise level. It's not possible to get a historical view of trends across your enterprise. With this feature, users will be able to see a trend of security feature enablement and security alerts at the enterprise level.

How will it work?

We will offer two new pages in security overview at the enterprise level similar to what we'll offer at the organization level: security coverage trends and risk trends that will house trends graphs for the following security features:

  • Dependabot alerts
  • Code scanning alerts
  • Secret scanning alerts
  • Push protection (enablement trends graph only)
  • GitHub Advanced Security (enablement trends graph only)
items.title: View a trend of security feature enablement/security alerts for your enterprise

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature enables you to export data on the security coverage and security risk pages in either CSV or JSON formats, providing a more efficient way to analyze and manipulate data.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users require the ability to analyze data using various creative approaches not intended to be supported by the product. This feature provides users with the ability to analyze and manipulate data more efficiently, improving overall productivity and data analysis.

How will it work?

You will be able to click the export button on the security coverage or security risk page and select the desired export format, either CSV or JSON. Data from all pages within the view will be exported.
items.title: Export security coverage and security risk data in security overview to CSV or JSON

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature enables you to generate a report of security alerts occurring during a specified period and export the results in either CSV or PDF formats.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users must comply with strict security regulations that require producing transactional reports of security alerts. The reports must meet specific requirements and, generally, must be generated by the security vendor directly. This feature streamlines the compliance reporting process, enabling users to generate reports that meet regulatory standards.

How will it work?

You will be able to specify a reporting period and generate a report of security alerts that occurred during that period. The report will be able to be generated in either CSV or PDF format.
items.title: Code security transaction report in CSV and PDF formats

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature enables you to filter security overview data by programming language, providing a more efficient way to analyze and manage security risks at both enterprise and organizational levels.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users have requested the ability to filter by programming language, streamlining the process of identifying and resolving security risks.

How will it work?

In the security overview, you can utilize the search bar located at the top of each page, such as the security risk and coverage pages. The search bar is a useful tool that allows you to manage data on the page efficiently.

With this feature, programming language filters will be automatically available via the search bar.
items.title: Programming language filter in security overview

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature provides for addiitonal views of code security—at the enterprise and repository level, presenting critical metrics to evaluate your security and identify areas for improvement.

Intended Outcome

Security managers face challenges in analyzing the extensive data generated by security products. The volume of alerts can be overwhelming, leading to critical questions such as, "Are we making progress?" "Where should we focus our efforts?" and "What are our priorities?" This dashboard enables security managers to make informed decisions, prioritize tasks, and monitor progress, enhancing code security and ultimately reducing vulnerability.

How will it work?

The security overview dashboard will serve as the primary view for code security, providing a comprehensive analysis of critical metrics that drive behavior. You'll be able to access the dashboard by clicking on the security tab, displaying a visually intuitive, one-page view of the most relevant information to achieve your code security objectives.
items.title: Comprehensive code security analysis with an enterprise-level and repository-level security overview dashboard

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature provides an organization-level view of code security, presenting critical metrics to evaluate your security and identify areas for improvement.

Intended Outcome

Security managers face challenges in analyzing the extensive data generated by security products. The volume of alerts can be overwhelming, leading to critical questions such as, "Are we making progress?" "Where should we focus our efforts?" and "What are our priorities?" This dashboard enables security managers to make informed decisions, prioritize tasks, and monitor progress, enhancing code security and ultimately reducing vulnerability.

How will it work?

The security overview dashboard will serve as the primary view for code security, providing a comprehensive analysis of critical metrics that drive behavior across the organization. You'll be able to access the dashboard by clicking on the security tab, displaying a visually intuitive, one-page view of the most relevant information to achieve your code security objectives.
items.title: Comprehensive code security analysis with an organization-level security overview dashboard

items.content_html:
Summary

This feature enhances the three alert-centric views (Dependabot, code scanning, and secret scanning) in security overview by enabling you to dynamically group alerts by various attributes such as repository, ecosystem, CVE, and team.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users need to be able to group the number of security alerts by specific attributes, such as a particular CVE or team. Currently, the only way to do this is to download data via the REST API and summarize it in a spreadsheet. This feature aims to provide users with more dynamic views to quickly identify the most critical security risks and prioritize remediation efforts.

How will it work?

You will be able to select an attribute to group by via a drop-down at the top of each of the three alert-centric views: Dependabot, code scanning, and secret scanning. Security alerts will be grouped by the selected attribute, and aggregate counts will be displayed, similar to how GitHub Projects functions.
items.title: Security overview alert-centric view dynamic grouping

items.content_html:
Summary

Currently, projects can only support 1200 active items and 10,000 archived items but we've heard from many larger teams that these limits are too low for the work they need to track such as long-running backlogs. While we can't completely remove the limit for projects, we will raise the limit to approximately 50k active items to better support this scenario.

Intended Outcome

For long running projects or all-encompassing backlogs for companies, the current limit for project items is too constricting. In order to better serve our large team and enterprise customers, we need to increase this limit so that their projects can grow as they do.

How will it work?

Projects will work as they do now, just with a higher upper limit on active items.
items.title: Projects: Increase project item limit

items.content_html:
Summary

When upgrading to a new version of GHES we do not provide any information about how the upgrade is progressing. We know that running the necessary database migrations is one of the longest parts of any upgrade, so we want to provide more insight into how this step of the upgrade is progressing.

Intended Outcome

Starting in GitHub Enterprise Server 3.9, enterprise administrators will be able to see the progress of the migrations that are running as part of an upgrade in real time.

How will it work?

We will print concise and easy-to-read information to the SSH console about the migrations that are running during an upgrade. Administrators will be able to monitor this information in real time to see how the migrations are progressing.
items.title: GitHub Enterprise Server: See how migrations are progressing during an upgrade

items.content_html:
Summary

Today, there is no way for consumer of individual actions to determine its trustworthiness and quality, other than analyzing whether it comes from a verified creator. Enterprises have been asking for actions that follow standards (e.g: CodeQL, timely dependency updates, etc.).

When this work is complete, we will automatically run checks on repositories hosting published Actions to determine if the repository where the Action is hosted follows security best practices. We use a subset of OpenSSF (Open Source Security Foundation) scorecard checks to make this determination and publish that metadata as part of the Action listing page and details.

Intended Outcome

We are building this to continue our credibility with customers that GitHub is serious about security. With 17K actions on the Marketplace and more getting added every day, it's imperative that we surface the necessary metadata for consumers to be able to make decisions about what actions they can rely on.

How will it work?

Whenever there's a state change in a repository (based on certain rules) a dynamic workflow is kicked off to run the checks. The results from the scoring are then surfaced on to the listing page. Since it's a new change, once we go GA, we will give action creators a grace period to make any desired changes, after which the results will be automatically published to the listing details page. New actions authored and published after the GA date will automatically get graded.

These checks against a repository that's hosting the action will evaluate holistic security practices, source risk assessment and build risk assessment.
items.title: Automatic security check information on each Actions listing

items.content_html:
Summary

Previously, customers needed to store this configuration data as encrypted secrets in order to reuse values in Actions features like reusable workflows. While extremely secure, this method did not allow for easy storage and retrieval of non-sensitive configuration data such as compiler flags, usernames, or server names.

Configuration variables allow you to store your non sensitive data as plain text variables that can be reused across your workflows in your repository or organization. You can define variables at Organization, Repository, or Environment level based on your requirement.

Intended Outcome

  • Configuration variables help developers define their non-sensitive information as plain text variables that can be consumed across multiple workflows in the repository.
  • Configuration variables allows you to define default parameters for tools like our Java compiler at an organization level, but permit individual development teams to override them as they see fit.
  • Configuration variables help DevOps team to provide a ‘golden path’ for build and deployment patterns while still allowing customization and control by the developers we support.

How will it work?

  • Customer can create new Variables at Organization, Repository and Environment level.
  • Customers can refer to the value of the variable in the workflow documents using the contruct ${{vars.<variable name>}}
  • The inheritance model for variables i.e. Org, Repo, Env work similar to secrets.
items.title: GitHub Actions configuration variables - GA

items.content_html:
Summary

Previously, to create a custom starter workflow, customers needed to add their starter workflows to a public .github repository in their organization. However, organizations don't want to maintain their custom starter workflows in a public repository. Now, org admins have control to choose their own repository(s) (public/private/internal) in the organization to store their custom starter workflows. Any workflow stored in starter-workflows folder in the chosen repositories will be shown as a org suggested starter workflows for the developer.

And we are also enhancing the new workflow experience in the repository. You will see a dedicated page for showing organization starter workflows.

Intended Outcome

Org admins can choose specific repositories (public, private, internal) of their choice to maintain their custom starter workflows. Developers can see the org suggested starter workflows when they try to create a new workflow.

How will it work?

  • Org admin configures the set of repositories to use for storing starter workflows.
  • Team members can contribute and store the starter workflows in the starter-workflows folder in the chosen repositories.
  • The visibility of the repository decides in what repositories the starter workflow shows up as a suggestion.
  • When a developer clicks on new workflow in a repository, he/she can see the org suggested starter workflows in a separate section.
items.title: GitHub Actions Starter workflow improvements

items.content_html:
Summary

We are now adding support for built-in protection rules which can be natively enabled on all environments. These would compliment the community powered custom protection rules which are powered by GitHub Apps.

Intended Outcome

Built-in protection rules enable us to provide key CD capabilities within "environments" by default. These preempt the experience for “discovery” and “installation” needed by custom rules powered by "GitHub Apps".

How will it work?

Built-in protection rules make “Environments” more robust with native gating capabilities which tie into the other GitHub features that we support across our product.
items.title: Actions: Built-in deployment protection rules (gates)
